transcript:
Patient: I've been doing my best to keep up with the Positive Data Log, but it's been a bit challenging to remember to write things down every day.

Therapist: That's understandable, Arjun. Building new habits takes time and practice. What have you been able to record in your Positive Data Log so far?

Patient: I've written down a few things, like when I received a compliment from my boss at work or when I was able to help my sister with her homework without getting frustrated.

Therapist: Those are great examples, Arjun. Even if you're not able to record something every day, the fact that you're making an effort to notice and acknowledge these positive experiences is a big step forward. Remember, the goal of the Positive Data Log is to help you gather evidence that supports your new core belief, "I am good enough." Each entry, no matter how small it may seem, is a piece of evidence that reinforces this belief.

Patient: I guess you're right. It's just hard to focus on the positive when there's so much negativity around me.

Therapist: I hear you, Arjun. It's easy to get caught up in the negative, especially when you're dealing with a lot of stress and responsibility. That's why it's so important to intentionally look for and acknowledge the positive moments, even if they seem small. Over time, this practice can help shift your overall perspective and make it easier to recognize your own worth and accomplishments.

Patient: I'll keep trying. It's just hard sometimes.

Therapist: I know it's not easy, Arjun, but you're doing a great job. Remember, you don't have to do this perfectly. Every effort you make is a step in the right direction. Let's take a look at your Positive Data Log together and see if we can find any patterns or themes in the evidence you've collected so far.

Patient: Okay, that sounds good.

Therapist: As we review your log, let's pay attention to how each entry relates to your new core belief, "I am good enough." We can also discuss any challenges you faced in recording these experiences and brainstorm strategies to make it easier for you to consistently notice and log positive evidence moving forward.

Patient: That would be really helpful. I want to keep working on this, even if it's difficult.

Therapist: Your determination is admirable, Arjun. Let's dive in and see what insights we can gain from your Positive Data Log.
